job_title: Learning Tech Specialist in Stoke-on-Trent, England
pros:
- Good for working from home, quite flexible working hours if required
- Most staff are friendly and happy to help, really nice community of polite workers
- Lovely campus and people seem to care about the university's reputation
cons:
- Uncertain  jobs and responsibilities, lots of talks about fictional ideas but the outcomes of these discussions don't work in reality so your time and effort is wasted
- There's job opportunities for egoist management to sit in meetings all day and talk, but lack of career growth for specialists or skilled workers
- Too many meetings yet little progress made. It's like a talking competition of who can say the best idea but there's no real desire or resource to carry it out. Unfortunately this is a waste of people's time and abilities

review_title: A Good place to work overall
job_title: IT Professional in Newcastle under Lyme, England
pros:
- Flexible working hours.
- Never short of things to do.
- 4 extra days annual leave after 5 years service.
- 5 Additional discretionary days ( usually over Christmas).
- Large scenic campus with woodlands.
cons:
- Not many career development opportunities if you stay in post, arrive with a grade you are happy with or you'll feel the need to move on to somewhere else eventually.

- parking can be a bit of a pain if you need to start a bit later.

- Certain areas of the IT Department are currently under staffed.
- IT Budgets can be tight at times, be prepared to bring out the gaffer tape.

- If you show an interest about how to solve a problem then you automatically end up being the owner of that problem and hence forth it is now your problem forever more.

review_title: Fantastic for students who can secure the job throughout uni
pros:
I worked at Keele SU as a Bar Assistant during my 2nd and 3rd year. 

- Amazing relationships between colleagues and management 

- Fully flexible around my studies as I was asked to specify the number of days (Mon - Sun) and times (AM/PM) that I could work on a week by week basis 

- Could swap shifts with others at very short notice! 

- Got promoted after 1 year as others graduated from uni! 

- Once you are employed, you pretty much have 95% chance of keeping your job throughout your uni course if you want to. The 5% account for stealing/giving away free drinks
cons:
- Often required to work the big SU events (unless 3rd year then you get priority to have it off!)

Other than that, none! Obviously the bar close down could take 1 hour after close (so often would be >4am by the time we went home). However, we would pull together to complete this as quick as possible.

job_title: Seasonal Teacher in Newcastle under Lyme, England
pros: Leafy campus, not far from major English cities. Staffordshire is a beautiful county. The university has world-class sports facilities. The university has a lot of potential to be a top-class university focused on long-running specialisms such as biotech and the environment but senior management and academics use the university as a stepping stone to bigger things.
cons: The university is notoriously bad at paying its sessional staff properly or on time. Standards vary wildly between departments. Some are flush with cash, others are under-resourced, under-staffed and mismanaged. Too much of the university's money is spent on vanity projects and trying to grow the university in an unrealistic and unsustainable manner.

review_title: Hands-off management has pros and cons
pros: The small size of the university promotes close working across disciplines and between academic and professional support staff. There are lots of opportunities to develop new skills and experience. Teaching development is taken seriously and student development is effectively designed.
cons: Things fall between the cracks and there are few effective specialists in any area. Procedures are often impractical or overlooked. Resources are stretched and this can lead to high workloads and expectations of do-it-yourself in many areas. Very limited mentoring or promotion prospects. No effective training or investment in staff.

pros: Stable steady job, great people with diversity of work load.
cons: There is an element of left hand doesn't talk to right because the University is so large, we're all in our own little zones so cross communication can prove a challenge at times but we make it work

job_title: University Representative Student in Newcastle under Lyme, England
pros:
Masters help is good
appropriate number of lecturers or assistants per pupil, depending on course/level
decent raking compared to other unis
cons: not particularly well respected, most other employers have never heard of the university or its location and you often have to explain its prowess to other people.

pros:
You'll meet lots of people you will love
Salary (Definitely high for the area)
Leave allowance
Lively environment with entertainment for students etc, lakes, woodland and wonderful wildlife
cons:
You'll meet lots of people you will not like
Some departments are 'its who you know, not what'
Expected workloads for some individuals whilst not so for others
Time to take your leave allowance
Parking - absolute nightmare if you're not extremely early every day

pros:
Fellow PhD students provide a good community. 
Flexible working hours. 
Welcoming environment. 
Nice campus and surrounding area.
cons:
Parking spaces are limited and between early working hours (09:00-13:00) spaces can be difficult to come by on campus. Parking spaces have since been opened up slightly off-campus with a 10-15 minute walk to campus.

Entertainment on campus is limited.
